subject: Re: Junit support for non-standard distributed applicatio ns

messageBody:
Chris,

> I'm wondering if you could be clever and just run all the
tests on
> the same machine by putting the client and the server on the same
machine
> (within the same vm even).

Yes, running all the tests in separate JVMs of the same host is what
I'm trying to do in a first step. Actually I started by running them
in a single JVM but this introduced side-effects because my team's
IPC components were not designed to be used this way...

> Remember that the point of JUnit is not to
> functionally test the software. It is to unit test it. Try to break
down
> your code into small testable pieces. By testing each piece you
will have
> greater control and more confidence that it will work once you put
it
> together. It may not even be necessary to run the client and server
at the
> same time if you take this approach; the test case could act as the
server
> for testing the client and vice-versa. These are just a few
thoughts -- the
> details of your particular program may prevent such an approach.
But if you
> are testing your code from the very beginning you shouldn't have
too much
> trouble doing it.

I agree I'm trying to use JUnit for functional tests rather than unit
tests for which it was designed. This piece of code is some existing
code that needs to be tested and was not designed from the start with
testability in mind. Consequently, it's not so easy to break it into
small parts for tests without investing a fair amount of time.

The reason I'm trying to use Junit for functional tests is that the
Junit execution environment is convenient and well integrated into
our Java-base development process: Junit is integrated into ANT and
cruisecontrol, the two tools supporting automatic build environment
including automatic test execution, collection of logs, analysis of
test results and notification of test failures.

Do you know an alternative to the Junit framework (i.e. a better
approach) to support automated functional tests that include more
than one process (and possibly more than one computer). The goal
still being to run these tests "continuously" and to reduce manual
tasks to a minimum in order to detect introduced bugs as soon as
possible?

Thanks,

Guillaume.
